G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: 4. This Court has subject matter jurisdiction and venue is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the events occurred within Quincy, Norfolk County, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Quincy District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: 4. This Court has subject matter jurisdiction and venue is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the events occurred within Quincy, Norfolk County, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Quincy District Court.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: 20. Property owners and occupiers in Massachusetts owe lawful visitors the duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining their premises in a safe condition.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and holding that lawful visitors are owed a duty of reasonable care in the maintenance of premises. Although the excerpt provided is only a concurrence and focuses on trespassers, the case as a whole clearly establishes the general negligence standard for lawful visitors. Thus, citing Mounsey for the proposition that Massachusetts owners/occupiers owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care is accurate.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt:
(From the majority opinion in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973)):

"We hold that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. The common law distinctions between licensees and invitees are hereby abolished in this Commonwealth, and the standard to be applied is whether in the management of his property the landowner has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others."

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: 20. Property owners and occupiers in Massachusetts owe lawful visitors the duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining their premises in a safe condition.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the general Massachusetts rule that owners or possessors of land owe a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, including the obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition. Although the holding ultimately concerns the absence of a duty to alter an adjacent state highway, the court clearly affirms the baseline premises-liability duty described in the proposition.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: 21. Defendant, as a business owner, owed Plaintiff, a lawful invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep its premises free from dangerous and unsafe conditions and to warn of such hazards.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes the traditional and current Massachusetts premises-liability rule for invitees, stating that a property owner owes lawful visitors (formerly invitees) a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe, including repairing or removing dangerous conditions or warning of such dangers. The court then applies that same reasonable-care standard to hazards from snow and ice on business premises. This squarely supports the proposition that a business owner owes a lawful invitee a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep premises free from dangerous conditions and to warn of such hazards.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: 21. Defendant, as a business owner, owed Plaintiff, a lawful invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep its premises free from dangerous and unsafe conditions and to warn of such hazards.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly grounds its analysis in general premises-liability principles drawn from Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 and prior Massachusetts law, which impose on store owners a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe for invitees and to protect them against dangerous conditions. Although the case’s main innovation concerns notice and the mode-of-operation approach, it reaffirms that a store owner must maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and take reasonable precautions commensurate with foreseeable risks—consistent with the claimed duty to keep premises free from dangerous conditions and warn/protect lawful invitees.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965), states: ‘A possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to his invitees by a condition on the land if, but only if, he (a) knows or by the exercise of reasonable care would discover the condition, and should realize that it involves an unreasonable risk of harm to such invitees… and (c) fails to exercise reasonable care to protect them against the danger.’ … [A] store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: 22. Defendant breached that duty by failing to clean the spilled water and ice within a reasonable time, and by failing to place any warning or “wet floor” signage despite actual and constructive notice of the dangerous condition.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The case discusses the general duty of a premises controller to use due care to keep premises reasonably safe or warn of dangers, but it does not hold that the defendant in this case breached that duty by failing to clean or post warnings. Instead, the court finds the evidence insufficient to infer that the foreign substance was present long enough to impose liability and ultimately orders judgment for the defendant. Thus, the opinion does not support a proposition that the defendant breached its duty under the described circumstances; it points the opposite way on the sufficiency of notice and breach.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: 1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. … 2. … There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required. … Exceptions sustained. Judgment for the defendant.

*Thurlow v. Crossman*, 336 Mass. 248 (19.proposition: 23. Defendant’s employees had actual knowledge of the wet floor and chose to delay corrective action, increasing the risk of injury to customers.
*Thurlow v. Crossman*, 336 Mass. 248 (19.support_reasoning: The case is about whether a state enforcement officer was a trespasser when he entered private property in the course of his duties. It does not involve a wet floor, premises liability, store employees, or any allegation that employees knew of a hazardous condition and delayed corrective action. The opinion provides no support for the claimed proposition regarding actual knowledge of a wet floor and increased risk to customers.
*Thurlow v. Crossman*, 336 Mass. 248 (19.relevant_excerpt: "The defendant in his capacity as enforcement officer was authorized, in the performance of his duties, to ‘enter upon and pass through or over private property or lands whether or not covered by water.’ ... It appears from the findings of the auditor that the defendant entered the premises to investigate suspected illegal activities relating to the taking of shellfish in the vicinity, a purpose within the scope of his duties as law enforcement officer..."

*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.raw_text: *Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 343 Mass. 263 (1961)
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.proposition: 24. Defendant’s failure to take timely action constituted a breach of its duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.support_reasoning: The case discusses the defendant’s duty to keep premises reasonably safe and the need for a reasonable opportunity to discover and remedy a dangerous condition, but it holds that the plaintiff failed to prove the defendant was negligent. The court finds there was insufficient evidence that the oil had been on the floor long enough or that employees had an adequate opportunity to discover and act on it. Thus, the opinion rejects, rather than affirms, a claim that the defendant’s failure to take timely action breached its duty of reasonable care.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.relevant_excerpt: “Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action… In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

*Cameron v. Kenney*, 321 Mass. 578 (1947.proposition: 24. Defendant’s failure to take timely action constituted a breach of its duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
*Cameron v. Kenney*, 321 Mass. 578 (1947.support_reasoning: The opinion is decided on statutory liability under G.L. c. 143, §§ 21 and 51, not on a common-law duty of reasonable care or a failure to take timely action. The court expressly declines to analyze the negligence counts once it finds a statutory violation and does not discuss any issue of timeliness in the defendant’s conduct. Thus, it does not establish that a defendant’s failure to act timely constitutes a breach of reasonable care under Massachusetts common-law negligence principles.
*Cameron v. Kenney*, 321 Mass. 578 (1947.relevant_excerpt: “The question remains whether the statute was in fact violated. There was evidence from which the jury could find that the cantilever was not ‘in good repair’ and ‘ready for use’ within the intent of the statute.… Since the plaintiffs were entitled to go to the jury on the statutory counts, we forbear discussion as to whether there was also a case for the jury on the counts based upon negligence.”

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.proposition: 25. The dangerous condition was open and obvious to Defendant’s employees, but not to Plaintiff, who had no reason to anticipate that an unmarked hallway would be wet and slippery.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.support_reasoning: The case concerns the open-and-obvious doctrine and a landowner’s duty to remedy an obvious danger, not a situation where the condition was open and obvious to the defendant’s employees but not to the plaintiff. The court analyzes duties assuming the danger (trampoline next to shallow pool) was open and obvious to a reasonable person, including the plaintiff, and never suggests it was hidden or non-obvious to him. The proposition about an unmarked wet hallway and differing knowledge between employees and plaintiff is not addressed in this opinion.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.relevant_excerpt: “In the present case, it is undisputed that defendants had a trampoline and inflatable pool in their backyard… you must decide whether the dangerous condition that he encountered and which caused his injury was open and obvious to a person of average intelligence… Whether other people may have engaged in this activity may be considered by you, but the question that you must decide is whether the danger of injury from engaging in this activity with the trampoline and the pool was open and obvious to a person of average intelligence.”

*Joly v. First Nat\u2019l Stores, Inc.*,.raw_text: *Joly v. First Nat’l Stores, Inc.*, 382 Mass. 14 (1980)
*Joly v. First Nat\u2019l Stores, Inc.*,.proposition: 26. Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
*Joly v. First Nat\u2019l Stores, Inc.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns statutory authority over mandatory sewer connections and the validity of a town meeting vote; it does not involve a negligence claim, personal injuries, or analysis of causation. There is no discussion of a defendant’s breach of duty, nor of direct or proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries. Thus, it provides no support for the proposition that a defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries.
*Joly v. First Nat\u2019l Stores, Inc.*,.relevant_excerpt: “We think the public health and safety are fully protected by the explicit power granted to the board of health by G. L. c. 83, § 11. The power of the sewer commissioners under § 10 is naturally read as relating to the manner of connecting rather than the requirement of connection, and § 3 seems to confirm that reading.”

*Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 336 Mass..proposition: 26. Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
*Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 336 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a bankruptcy/trustee action about the validity of a corporate chattel mortgage and related payments; it does not discuss negligence, causation, or personal injuries. The court’s analysis addresses corporate authority, fraudulent conveyance, and benefits to the corporation, not whether a defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries. Therefore, it does not support the stated negligence-causation proposition.
*Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 336 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We think, for reasons to be stated, that the payments under the mortgage may not be attacked under these provisions because the mortgage was a valid corporate obligation and was not a fraudulent conveyance under the statute.”

*G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85*.proposition: As a further result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has suffered and continues to suffer pain, emotional distress, medical expenses, loss of wages, and diminished enjoyment of life. *G.L. c. 231, § 85* governs comparative negligence and imposes liability when the defendant’s negligence is greater than the plaintiff’s, which applies here.

*G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C*.proposition: 30. Plaintiff seeks costs allowable under *Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d)* and interest pursuant to *G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C*.
